questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with a superficial burn injury involving the upper limbs. Examination reveals erythema and peeling of the outermost layer of skin, but no blistering or deep tissue involvement. Which of the following correctly represents the order of the epidermal layers affected in this injury, from deep to superficial?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

S. basale, S. spinosum, S. granulosum, S. corneum represents the order of the epidermal layers affected in this injury, from deep to superficial.

  • The epidermis is a keratinised, stratified, squamous epithelium.
  • It is thinnest on the eyelid and thickest on the palms and soles.
  • The epidermis has five layers in palms and soles, referred to as 'thick skin'.
  • The rest of the body has four layers and is classified as thin skin.
  • In the thin skin, four layers from deep to superficial are:
    • Stratum basale
    • Stratum spinosum
    • Stratum granulosum
    • Stratum corneum
  • The thick skin has an extra fifth layer, called the stratum lucidum, sandwiched between the stratum corneum and stratum granulosum.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with a scaly, red plaque on the forearm. A skin biopsy is performed, and histology shows keratinocytes connected by numerous desmosomes, as given in the image, under the microscope. Which layer of the epidermis is most likely being described?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

  • Stratum spinosum is also called the prickle cell layer because the cells are held together with spiny projections of the intercellular attachments called desmosomes between keratinocytes.
  • The spiny appearance is due to the shrinking of the microfilaments between desmosomes that occurs during the process of H&E staining.

Stratum basale (Option A): The deepest epidermal layer containing mitotically active basal keratinocytes and melanocytes.

Stratum granulosum (Option C): A layer where keratinocytes begin keratinisation and accumulate keratohyalin granules.

Stratum corneum (Option D): The outermost layer of dead, flattened, keratinised cells, providing a waterproof barrier.

questions.text: A patient with psoriasis shows marked epidermal hyperplasia on histopathology. The proliferation is primarily observed in the layers responsible for mitotic activity. These layers together form which part of the epidermis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The Malpighian Layer is composed of two Layers:

The basal layer (stratum basale) and the spinous layer (stratum spinosum).

  • The basal layer contains mitotically active (germinal) cells that divide and give rise to new epidermal cells, forming the basis of epidermal regeneration.
  • The cells from the basal layer divide and move outward to form the spinous layer; together, these layers are responsible for cell division and the early stages of keratinocyte differentiation.

Source of Keratinocytes:

  • The keratinocytes of the outer epidermis originate from cells of the Malpighian layer.

Role in Skin Renewal:

  • The Malpighian layer replenishes the upper layers (granular and cornified) by continuous cell division and upward migration.

The basal layer is the mitotically active layer that divides to give rise to the outer population of cells that constitutes the spinous layer.

Stratum spinosum and stratum granulosum (Option B): The granulosum is involved in keratinisation, not active mitosis.

Stratum granulosum and stratum lucidum (Option C): Both are non-mitotic, more involved in the terminal differentiation of keratinocytes.

Stratum granulosum and stratum corneum (Option D): These are the upper, dead or terminally differentiated layers; no mitosis occurs here.

questions.text: A neonate born at 26 weeks of gestation has fragile, shiny skin and requires special humidified care to reduce transepidermal water loss. Which of the following epidermal layers is primarily responsible for this immaturity in the skin barrier?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Stratum corneum is primarily responsible for the immaturity in the skin barrier.

In the development of the epidermis, the layers form sequentially from the basal layer upward. The stratum basale is the first to develop, followed by the stratum spinosum, stratum granulosum, and finally the stratum corneum.

  • In very low birth weight (VLBW) infants, especially those born preterm, the stratum corneum is underdeveloped at birth, often consisting of only 2-3 cell layers.
  • This immature barrier is thin and highly permeable, leading to increased transepidermal water loss and transcutaneous heat loss, and has difficulty in maintaining homeostasis.
  • Postnatally, the stratum corneum undergoes rapid maturation, typically reaching a structure similar to that of full-term infants by 2 to 3 weeks of age.

Stratum basale (Option A): This is the basal proliferative layer, but not directly responsible for the skin's barrier function.

Stratum spinosum (Option B): Important for structural integrity and desmosomal connections, but not the main barrier against water loss.

Stratum granulosum (Option D): Involved in keratinisation and forming lamellar bodies, but the final barrier is formed by the stratum corneum.

questions.text: In which layer of the epidermis is profilaggrin primarily stored?
questions.solution:
• Profilaggrin is found in the keratohyalin granules present in the stratum granulosum.
  • Profilaggrin breaks down to yield individual filaggrin monomers at the transition between the stratum granulosum and stratum corneum.
  • Deficiency of filaggrin: Atopic dermatitis & Ichthyosis vulgaris.
  • Filaggrin is a protein component of the keratohyalin granule.
    • It promotes the aggregation of keratin filaments in corneocytes.
    • This aggregation leads to the formation of disulfide cross-linked macrofibres.
    • Filaggrin is later broken down into hygroscopic amino acids.
    • These amino acids contribute to the natural moisturising factor (NMF) in corneocytes.
    • Loss-of-function mutations in the filaggrin gene cause ichthyosis vulgaris.
    • These mutations are also a major risk factor for atopic eczema, atopic asthma, and systemic allergies.

Stratum corneum (Option A): This layer contains fully keratinised, dead cells; filaggrin (not profilaggrin) is active here but not stored here.

Stratum spinosum (Option C): Keratinocytes here are actively synthesising structural proteins, but keratohyalin granules (which store profilaggrin) appear only in the layer above.

Stratum basale (Option D): This is the basal proliferative layer; profilaggrin synthesis begins later in keratinocyte maturation, not stored here.

questions.text: Odland bodies are present in _____.
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Odland bodies are present in the stratum granulosum.

  • Odland bodies (also known as lamellar granules or membrane-coating granules) originate in the upper stratum spinosum but become most abundant and functionally active in the stratum granulosum.
  • They contain lipids/sterols and discharge lipid components into the intercellular space that play the role of intercellular cement in the stratum corneum and perform the barrier function.
  • Odland bodies are secretory organelles found in keratinocytes.
  • They are rich in lipids and enzymes, and they play a crucial role in forming the skin's permeability barrier.
  • These bodies are formed in the upper stratum spinosum, but they become prominent and active in the stratum granulosum, where they release their contents into the intercellular space.

Stratum corneum (Option A): This layer contains dead, anucleate cells and no organelles; Odland bodies are already secreted by this stage.

Stratum lucidum (Option B): Found only in thick skin (palms/soles), this translucent layer lacks visible organelles like Odland bodies.

Stratum basale (Option D): This basal layer is responsible for cell division and doesn't produce or contain Odland bodies.

questions.text: In thick skin, such as the palms and soles, the translucent appearance of the stratum lucidum is due to the presence of which substance?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The translucent appearance of the stratum lucidum is due to the substance eleidin.

  • Stratum lucidum is a translucent layer of the epidermis seen only in thick skin (palms and soles), located between the stratum granulosum and stratum corneum.
  • The cells here are anucleate and filled with eleidin, a refractile protein that contributes to the translucent appearance of this layer.
  • Eleidin is derived from keratohyalin granules of the stratum granulosum.

Keratohyalin (Option A): Found in the stratum granulosum, not stratum lucidum; it's a precursor of profilaggrin, not responsible for translucency.

Melanin (Option B): A dark pigment located in basal keratinocytes and melanocytes; it provides skin colour, not translucency.

Tonofibrils (Option D) : Bundles of keratin filaments in keratinocytes, mainly in stratum spinosum; they provide mechanical strength, not a translucent appearance.

questions.text: What is the approximate duration of epidermal turnover in normal human skin?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Total epidermal turnover time is 40-56 days.

  • The epidermal turnover time, also known as the epidermal renewal or transit time, refers to the duration it takes for a basal keratinocyte to differentiate, move up through the layers, and be shed from the stratum corneum.
  • During the development of the epidermis, the first layer to form is S. Basale and subsequently, layers form from below upwards.
  • The principal function of the epidermis is the constant replacement of the stratum corneum, which is being continuously shed and replaced.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC2861991/

Melanocytes are present in the stratum basale.
squamous epithelium with hallmark keratin intermediate filaments.

questions.text: All of the following statements about skin are true, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

  • Langerhans cells are specialized antigen-presenting dendritic cells.
  • They are located mainly in the stratum spinosum of the epidermis.
  • They are derived from the bone marrow and play a key role in skin immunity by capturing and processing foreign antigens that enter through the skin and then migrating to nearby lymph nodes to activate T-cells.
  • They are characterised by surface markers like CD1a and Langerin (CD207), and contain unique rod-shaped organelles called Birbeck granules.
  • These cells are essential for initiating immune responses and are implicated in conditions like Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

Melanocytes originate from the neural crest and are present in the stratum basale. (Option B ruled out)

The epidermis is a keratinised, stratified, squamous epithelium, and the hallmark filaments are the keratin intermediate filaments. (Option C ruled out)

Merkel cells originate from the ectoderm and are present in the stratum basale. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following components in the skin protects from ultraviolet (UV) radiation?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Melanocytes give the protective response to UV exposure.

  • Melanocytes are specialised pigment-producing cells located in the stratum basale of the epidermis.
  • Melanocytes originate from neural crests.
  • They produce melanin and transfer it to keratinocytes.
  • They synthesise melanin, a pigment that absorbs and scatters ultraviolet (UV) radiation, helping to protect underlying skin cells from DNA damage.
  • With increased sun exposure, melanocytes enhance melanin production, leading to tanning-a protective response to UV exposure.
  • The ratio of melanocytes to keratinocytes is 1: 10 in the epidermal basal layer.

Horny layer (Option A): The stratum corneum (horny layer) provides a physical barrier against environmental insults but does not specifically absorb UV radiation.

Langerhans cells (Option B): These are immune cells involved in antigen presentation; they don't play a role in UV protection.

Keratinocyte (Option C): These cells receive melanin from melanocytes, but do not produce melanin themselves and are not directly responsible for UV protection.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3834696/

questions.text: A patient loses the ability to perceive fine touch and texture on their fingertips after a superficial skin injury. Which of the following sensory receptors is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Merkel cells form the neurite complex with sensory nerves hence any damage to them leads to loss of ability to perceive fine touch and texture.

Merkel Cells:

  • Found among basal keratinocytes.
  • Present in hairy skin, tactile areas of glabrous skin, taste buds, anal canal, labial epithelium, and eccrine sweat glands.
  • Innervated by a single slowly adapting type 1 nerve fibre.
  • Function:
    • Form the Merkel cell-neurite complex with sensory nerves.
    • Serve as slow-adapting mechanoreceptors for sustained touch and pressure.
    • Exhibit touch-evoked mechanotransduction currents.
    • Establish excitatory synaptic connections with sensory neurons.
  • Clinical Associations:
    • Merkel cell carcinoma: Aggressive neuroendocrine cancer, often linked to Merkel cell polyomavirus.
    • Absent in vitiligo lesions (possible autoimmune/neural involvement).
    • Merkel cell hyperplasia is seen in:
      • Adnexal tumours (naevus sebaceus, trichoblastoma, etc.)
      • Neurofibromas, neurodermatitis, and nodular prurigo.

Meissner corpuscle (Option A) : These are touch receptors too, found in dermal papillae, but they detect light touch and low-frequency vibration, not detailed texture or fine discrimination.

Pacinian corpuscle (Option B) : Located deep in the dermis or subcutaneous tissue, they detect deep pressure and high-frequency vibration, not fine touch.

Langerhans cells (Option C) : These are immune cells involved in antigen presentation and have no role in sensory perception.

questions.text: Which of the following is an intracellular component of hemidesmosomes that links keratin intermediate filaments to the inner plaque?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

BPAg1 is the component of hemidesmosomes that links keratin intermediate filaments to the inner plaque.

Hemidesmosomes:

  • Found at the dermal-epidermal junction.
  • Intracellular Connections:
    • Attach to the keratin intermediate filament network inside basal keratinocytes.
    • Inner plaques contain:
      • Plectin
      • Bullous pemphigoid antigen 1 (BPAG1 or 230 kDa antigen)
      • BPAG2 (180 kDa antigen) or type XVII collagen (a transmembrane protein of the plakin family).
  • Extracellular Connections:
    • In the lamina lucida, hemidesmosomes connect with anchoring filaments.
    • Anchoring filaments are mainly composed of laminin 332 (a trimer of α3, β3, and γ2 chains).
  • Clinical Relevance:
    • Mutations in hemidesmosomal proteins cause various forms of epidermolysis bullosa (EB).
    • Loss of laminin 332 leads to severe generalised junctional EB.

K5/K14 (Option A) : These are keratin intermediate filaments that get linked by BPAg1, but they are not part of the hemidesmosomal plaque themselves.

Nidogen (Option C) : A basement membrane component that links laminin to collagen IV; not part of the hemidesmosome structure.

Laminin (Option D) : An extracellular glycoprotein in the basement membrane (especially laminin-332 in skin), involved in linking hemidesmosomes to the ECM, but not an intracellular component.

questions.text: The structural integrity between adjacent keratinocytes in the epidermis is maintained by which of the following junctions?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Desmosomes maintain the structural integrity between adjacent keratinocytes in the epidermis.

  • Desmosomes are major adhesion complexes in the epidermis, anchoring keratin intermediate filaments to the cell membrane.
  • They bridge adjacent keratinocytes, enabling resistance to mechanical trauma.
  • Also found in other tissues: myocardium, meninges, gastrointestinal mucosa, bladder, and lymph node cortex. Max concentration is in spinous cells.
  • Desmosomes contain various proteins: Desmogleins, desmocollin and desmoplakin.
  • Damage to the desmosomes leads to the separation of keratinocytes, leading to acantholysis. The cells separate from each other, become round with a large nucleus and a perinuclear halo called acantholytic cells.

Explanation of other options:

Tight junctions (Option A) - These are found mainly in the upper layers of the epidermis (e.g., stratum granulosum) and serve to prevent paracellular leakage, not structural anchoring.

Gap junctions (Option B) - These allow intercellular communication, permitting the passage of ions and small molecules, but they don't contribute significantly to mechanical strength.

Hemidesmosomes (Option D) - These anchor basal keratinocytes to the basement membrane, not adjacent cells to each other.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with pemphigus has autoantibodies directed against proteins in which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Pemphigus is an autoimmune blistering disorder caused by autoantibodies against desmogleins, which are cadherin-type adhesion proteins located in desmosomes.

  • These antibodies disrupt cell-to-cell adhesion between keratinocytes in the epidermis.
  • This leads to loss of desmosomal integrity, resulting in the separation of keratinocytes and the formation of intraepidermal blisters.

Explanation of other options:

Keratinocytes (Option A) : While keratinocytes are affected in pemphigus, they are not the direct target of the autoantibodies; the attack is on desmosomes between them.

Melanocytes (Option B) : These pigment-producing cells are not involved in pemphigus pathogenesis.

Langerhans cells (Option D) : These are immune surveillance cells in the epidermis and are unrelated to desmosomal adhesion or pemphigus.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with chronic lichenified plaques over both shins due to repeated scratching. Skin biopsy reveals thickening of the stratum spinosum of the epidermis. What is this histopathological change called?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Acanthosis refers to an increase in the thickness of the stratum spinosum (prickle cell layer) of the epidermis due to proliferation of keratinocytes.

  • Commonly seen in chronic inflammatory or pruritic conditions like lichen simplex chronicus, where repeated scratching stimulates epidermal hyperplasia.
  • It leads to broadening and elongation of rete ridges, visible in histology.

Explanation of other options:

Spongiosis (Option A) is mainly intra-epidermal intercellular oedema in the epidermis.

Hypergranulosis (Option C) is an increased thickness of the stratum granulosum.

Hyperkeratosis (Option D) is a thickening of the stratum corneum, the outer layer of skin.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with violaceous, flat-topped, itchy papules over her wrists and ankles. A skin biopsy reveals degeneration of basal keratinocytes at the dermoepidermal junction. This histological finding is characteristic of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Basal cell degeneration refers to damage to the basal keratinocytes at the dermoepidermal junction, a hallmark of lichen planus caused by an immune-mediated attack on these cells.

The skin layer changes are as follows:

Stratum Basale:

  • Basal cell degeneration occurs in Lichen planus.

Stratum Spinosum:

  • Intercellular oedema → Spongiosis (Eczema, erythroderma)
  • Thickening → Acanthosis (Lichen planus)

Stratum Granulosum:

  • Thickening → Hypergranulosis (Lichen Planus)
  • Thinning → Hypogranulosis (Psoriasis)

Stratum Corneum:

  • Nucleated cells → Parakeratosis (Psoriasis, Actinic keratoses)
  • Thickening → Hyperkeratosis
  • Neutrophilic collection → Micromunro abscess (Psoriasis)

Psoriasis (Option B) : Shows regular acanthosis, parakeratosis, and neutrophils in the stratum corneum (Munro microabscesses), without basal layer degeneration.

Pemphigus (Option C) : Characterized by acantholysis (loss of cohesion between keratinocytes), especially suprabasal clefting, not basal cell degeneration.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with rough, scaly, erythematous patches on sun-exposed areas of his skin. Histology shows retention of nuclei in the outermost layer of the epidermis. Which of the following conditions is this finding most commonly associated with?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Parakeratosis is seen in actinic keratoses.

  • Normally, nuclei are absent in the stratum
  • Parakeratosis: Retention of nuclei within the cells of the stratum corneum.
  • Parakeratosis is seen in:
    • Normally→ Mucous membrane of mouth and vagina
    • Benign Disorders → Psoriasis, Seborrheic dermatitis
    • Malignant/Pre-malignant→Actinic keratosis, Squamous cell carcinoma

Explanation of other options:

Seborrheic keratoses (Option B) : These are benign pigmented lesions with hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, and horn cysts, but not typically parakeratosis or actinic damage.

Molluscum contagiosum (Option C) : A viral skin infection showing Henderson-Patterson bodies (large eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions), not parakeratosis or dysplasia.

Basal cell carcinoma (Option D) : Shows basaloid cell nests with peripheral palisading, but it does not present with parakeratosis as a key histologic feature.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents with multiple, itchy, greasy, skin-colored to brownish papules over the chest and back. A skin biopsy reveals acantholysis and dyskeratosis with the presence of corps ronds and grains in the epidermis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Darier's disease is an acantholytic disorder.

Dyskeratosis:

  • Refers to abnormal keratinisation of epidermal cells.
  • Histological features:
    • Nuclear pyknosis
    • Bright pink (eosinophilic) condensation of keratinocyte cytoplasm
  • Occurs in two main contexts:
    • Malignant and premalignant epithelial lesions:
      • Squamous cell carcinoma
      • Bowen disease
      • Solar (actinic) keratosis
    • Acantholytic disorders:
      • Example: Darier disease
        • Characteristic dyskeratotic cells:
          • Corps ronds
          • Grains

Explanation of other options:

Pemphigus vulgaris (Option B) presents with flaccid bullae and erosions, commonly involving the mucosa. Although acantholysis is present, dyskeratosis is not a defining feature, and the histology lacks corps ronds or grains; immunofluorescence typically reveals a fishnet pattern of IgG deposition.

Psoriasis (Option C) features erythematous plaques with silvery scales, usually on the extensor surfaces or scalp. Its histology includes parakeratosis and neutrophilic microabscesses, but dyskeratosis and acantholytic cells are not characteristic findings.

Lichen planus (Option D) typically presents with violaceous, flat-topped papules, often on flexor surfaces or mucosa, not greasy papules with crusting. Histology shows a band-like lymphocytic infiltrate and basal cell degeneration, but dyskeratosis and corps ronds/grains are absent.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male presents with blistering of the skin following minor trauma since early childhood. Genetic testing reveals a mutation affecting keratin filament assembly in the basal layer of the epidermis. Which of the following keratin filament pairs is most likely involved in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Mutations in K5/K14, expressed in the stratum basale, are associated with epidermolysis bullosa simplex, where mechanical stress leads to basal layer separation and blistering. K5/14 is present as an intermediate filament in the basal cell layer of and it connects to the hemidesmosomal plaque.

Epidermal Differentiation:

  • Stratum Corneum
    • Lipid bilayers
    • Cross-linked cornified envelope
    • Filaggrin
  • Granular Layer
    • Tight junctions
    • Lamellar granules
    • Keratohyalin granules
    • Keratin filament bundles
    • Profilaggrin
    • Loricrin
    • Lipids
  • Spinous Layer
    • K1/K10 keratin filament bundles
    • Intercellular junctions rich in desmosomes
    • Transcription factors and signaling proteins: AP2, C/EBP, Hes1, Notch1/2
  • Basal Layer
    • K5/K14 keratin filaments
    • Intercellular junctions rich in adherens junctions
    • Hemidesmosomes (αβ4 integrin)
    • Focal adhesions (α3β1 integrin)
    • Basement membrane proteins:
      • Laminin 32
      • Fibronectin
      • Collagen IV
    • Signaling molecules and receptors: p63, EGFR, IGFR, TGF-β, Delta1, IGFs, TGF-α

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with recurrent blisters and erosions over pressure points since infancy. Examination reveals fragile skin with healed scars over the elbows and knees. Skin biopsy shows separation at the dermoepidermal junction, and immunostaining reveals a defect in anchoring fibrils. A mutation in which type of collagen is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Type VII collagen is the major component of anchoring fibrils of the dermo-epidermal junction.

  • Anchoring fibrils attach the lamina densa above to the connective tissue in the dermis.
  • The rating of Type 1 to Type 3 collagen in the adult human skin is 8:1 and increases with age

Explanation of other options:

Type IV (Option A) : Found in the lamina densa of the basement membrane, but mutations cause defects in filtration (e.g., in Alport syndrome), not skin blistering.

Type III (Option C) : A component of reticular fibers in connective tissue; mutations are linked to vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, not blistering disorders.

Type II (Option D) : Found in cartilage, involved in skeletal development; not associated with skin integrity or blistering conditions.

questions.text: What is the ratio of Type 1 to Type 3 collagen in the adult human skin?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Most collagen fibrils are composed of several collagen types and are called heterotypic.
  • Collagen fibrils are made of collagens I and III in skin. Type 1 is the most abundant collagen in skin (80%), and the second most common is type 3.
  • Type 2 collagen is not found in skin and is unique to cartilage.
  • The ratio between type I and Ill collagen is 8:1 and increases with age

Explanation of other options:

1:4 (Option A) : Incorrect; this would suggest a predominance of Type III collagen, which is more typical of fetal or healing tissue, not adult skin.

3:2 (Option C) : Underestimates the dominance of Type I collagen in adult skin.

4:1 ( Option D) : Closer, but still underrepresents Type I's dominance.

choices.text: Skin accounts for 15% of total body weight
Dense irregular connective tissue is present in dermis
Dermis is made up of type 1 and type 3 collagen

questions.text: A medical intern is reviewing embryological origins during a dermatology rotation. Which of the following statements regarding the skin is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Langerhans cells and dermis originate from mesoderm.

  • Epidermis, keratinocytes, and Merkel cells originate from ectoderm.
  • Skin weight is 4-5 kg and makes up 15% of total body weight. (Option B ruled out)
  • Most collagen fibrils are composed of several collagen types and are called heterotypic.
  • Collagen fibrils are made of collagens I and III in skin. Type 1 is the most abundant collagen in skin (80%), and the second most common is type 3. Type 2 collagen is not found in skin and is unique to cartilage. The ratio between type I and Ill collagen is 8:1 and increases along with an increase in age. (Option D ruled out)
  • Dense irregular connective tissue is found in the dermis of the skin, the submucosa of the gut, below the loose connective tissue of the Lamina propria, and in the capsule surrounding organs. (Option C ruled out)
  • Extensive collagen fibres allow this type of tissue to withstand tension exerted in many directions, which provides structural strength and flexibility to organs.

Embryological development of the skin. A.) 4 weeks B.) 8 weeks C.) Newborn infant

Embryology of skin

  • The skin develops from two primary embryonic layers:
    • Ectoderm → forms the epidermis and its appendages (hair, nails, sweat glands, sebaceous glands).
    • Mesoderm → gives rise to the dermis, subcutaneous tissue, vessels, and connective tissue.
  • Disruptions during these stages can lead to congenital skin disorders like:
    • Ectodermal dysplasias
    • Incontinentia pigmenti
    • Ichthyoses
